dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Back in 2019, Uber just announced they're immediately complying with AB5, reclassifying all drivers as full-time employees.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Back in twenty nineteen, Uber just announced they're immediately complying with AB5, reclassifying all drivers as full-time employees.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Because the company believes its workers will still be classified correctly under the new measure, West said Uber will not be automatically reclassifying drivers to be employees in January, when the measure is likely to take effect.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they've even withdrawn that 30 million dollars they had set aside for a ballot measure, which is huge.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they've even withdrawn that thirty million dollars they had set aside for a ballot measure, which is huge.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Instead, Uber says it is prepared to fight any legal challenges in court and has set aside an additional $30 million for a ballot measure to provide workers with other benefits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Tony East, their chief legal officer, was practically jubilant about it—said they fully admit to misclassifying drivers for years.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Tony East, their chief legal officer, was practically jubilant about it-said they fully admit to misclassifying drivers for years.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We expect we will continue to respond to claims of misclassification in arbitration and in court as necessary, just as we do now, Tony West, Ubers chief legal officer, told reporters during a press call on Wednesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But wait, their argument is that they actually won't meet the stricter employment test under the bill, so they're expecting to just become a traditional taxi service?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But wait, their argument is that they actually won't meet the stricter employment test under the bill, so they're expecting to just become a traditional taxi service?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Ubers argument hinges on the belief that it will meet the standards of the stricter employment test set forth by the bill.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, which is such a wild pivot from their earlier stance. And California lawmakers actually voted against AB5 on Wednesday, so it's not even passing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, which is such a wild pivot from their earlier stance. And California lawmakers actually voted against AB5 on Wednesday, so it's not even passing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: California lawmakers passed Assembly Bill 5 on Wednesday, which largely requires companies to convert independent contractors to employees if their work is part of the companys main business or the company exerts control over their work.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, but Uber's moving forward with reclassifying drivers as employees starting in January anyway. Stock for both Uber and Lyft took a nosedive though.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, but Uber's moving forward with reclassifying drivers as employees starting in January anyway. Stock for both Uber and Lyft took a nosedive though.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Both Uber and Lyft stock closed in the green on Wednesday on the news that Governor Gavin Newsom, who had already promised to sign the ball, remains in talks with the companies, as first reported by the Wall Street Journal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Governor Newsom was pleased with the change of heart, apparently, even though he'd promised to veto the bill.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Governor Newsom was pleased with the change of heart, apparently, even though he'd promised to veto the bill.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Both Uber and Lyft stock closed in the green on Wednesday on the news that Governor Gavin Newsom, who had already promised to sign the ball, remains in talks with the companies, as first reported by the Wall Street Journal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's interesting how Uber's now saying their main business is drivers and rides, not this platform model they've defended for so long.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's interesting how Uber's now saying their main business is drivers and rides, not this platform model they've defended for so long.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Uber argues its main business is not drivers and rides, but being a technology platform for several different types of digital marketplaces.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And they're claiming drivers can't be signed into multiple apps at once, which feels like a new restriction.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they're claiming drivers can't be signed into multiple apps at once, which feels like a new restriction.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It also allows drivers to be signed into multiple services, from Lyft to food delivery companies, at once.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Feels like they're trying to avoid lawsuits altogether—they've always reached agreements instead of going to court.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Feels like they're trying to avoid lawsuits altogether-they've always reached agreements instead of going to court.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company has repeatedly faced court cases, often settling with drivers, but not changing their employment status.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Tony East even said something like, just because the test is easy doesn't mean we'll fail it? Which is such a weirdly confident way to put it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Tony East even said something like, just because the test is easy doesn't mean we'll fail it? Which is such a weirdly confident way to put it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Just because the test is hard, it doesnt mean we will not be able to pass it, West said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And now they're working separately from Lyft to oppose a new ballot measure that would offer fewer benefits for contracted workers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And now they're working separately from Lyft to oppose a new ballot measure that would offer fewer benefits for contracted workers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As part of its response, Uber is also coordinating with its rival Lyft to propose a new ballot measure that would offer better benefits for their independent contractor workforce, including a base pay rate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostLyft
dialogue_turns.text: HostLyft wasn't happy either—said the fact that less than 50 industries were carved out of AB5 was "uninspiring."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: HostLyft wasn't happy either-said the fact that less than fifty industries were carved out of AB5 was uninspiring.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The fact that there were more than 50 industries carved out of AB5 is very telling, Lyft said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So basically, both companies are trying to steer clear of court battles and public backlash by making these big promises, but the law didn't even pass.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So basically, both companies are trying to steer clear of court battles and public backlash by making these big promises, but the law didn't even pass.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: California lawmakers passed Assembly Bill 5 on Wednesday, which largely requires companies to convert independent contractors to employees if their work is part of the companys main business or the company exerts control over their work.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's a total 180 from how they operated in their earliest days, arguing existing laws didn't apply to them. Now they're embracing regulation, or at least pretending to.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a total one hundred eighty from how they operated in their earliest days, arguing existing laws didn't apply to them. Now they're embracing regulation, or at least pretending to.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Ubers defiant stance is a throwback to its earliest days of ride-hailing where it made similar arguments that existing laws around taxis and transportation also didnt apply to its business.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For now, at least. Let's see if they follow through come January.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For now, at least. Let's see if they follow through come January.

artist_script:
HostA: Back in 2019, Uber just announced they're immediately complying with AB5, reclassifying all drivers as full-time employees.
HostB: Yeah, and they’ve even withdrawn that 30 million dollars they had set aside for a ballot measure, which is huge.
HostA: Tony East, their chief legal officer, was practically jubilant about it—said they fully admit to misclassifying drivers for years.
HostB: But wait, their argument is that they actually won’t meet the stricter employment test under the bill, so they’re expecting to just become a traditional taxi service?
HostA: Exactly, which is such a wild pivot from their earlier stance. And California lawmakers actually voted against AB5 on Wednesday, so it’s not even passing.
HostB: Right, but Uber’s moving forward with reclassifying drivers as employees starting in January anyway. Stock for both Uber and Lyft took a nosedive though.
HostA: Governor Newsom was pleased with the change of heart, apparently, even though he’d promised to veto the bill.
HostB: It’s interesting how Uber’s now saying their main business is drivers and rides, not this platform model they’ve defended for so long.
HostA: And they’re claiming drivers can’t be signed into multiple apps at once, which feels like a new restriction.
HostB: Feels like they’re trying to avoid lawsuits altogether—they’ve always reached agreements instead of going to court.
HostA: Tony East even said something like, just because the test is easy doesn’t mean we’ll fail it? Which is such a weirdly confident way to put it.
HostB: And now they’re working separately from Lyft to oppose a new ballot measure that would offer fewer benefits for contracted workers.
HostLyft wasn’t happy either—said the fact that less than 50 industries were carved out of AB5 was "uninspiring."
HostA: So basically, both companies are trying to steer clear of court battles and public backlash by making these big promises, but the law didn’t even pass.
HostB: It’s a total 180 from how they operated in their earliest days, arguing existing laws didn’t apply to them. Now they’re embracing regulation, or at least pretending to.
HostA: For now, at least. Let’s see if they follow through come January.
